												Dwarfs!? is a strangely addicting game. If you enjoy arcade games, where the main objective is to beat your high score (or someone else's high score), you'll probably love this game.The way you score is by getting as much gold as you can, while trying to stay alive--but, you're dwarfs aren't the brightest and will insist on digging into caves filled with water, lava, and monsters, so you'll have to keep a close eye on them, which becomes harder and harder as the game progresses.The F2P version has the two easier difficulties unlocked and each can be played in 5, 15, 30, and 60 min sessions (but beware, you cannot save the game mid-session).The only problem I've encountered is in long games, where you have thousands of dwarfs in the field at one time, my computer starts to lag--which makes the game very difficult and frustrating to play.Overall, this is a fun, simple, casual game that can keep you entertained for hours or opened for a quick 5-minute session.[NOTE: If you buy the full version, your personal scores and achievements will transfer, but the F2P version has different global leaderboards, and your global score will not transfer.][EDIT: For those wondering, I personally own the full version (non-F2P), which is why my play-time on the F2P version is so low.]Concerning the DLC...Dwarfs - F2P Skirmish Pack (Recommended): Comes with 3 modes (Sandbox, Rush, and Dark). Rush and Dark modes bring new challenges to the game and can be a lot of fun. In Sandbox, you can experiment. In Rush, dwarfs spawn CONSTANTLY and you can only let 200 die. In Dark, you cannot see where caves or minerals are located.Dwarfs - F2P Difficulty Pack (Recommended): Unlocks the two harder difficulty levels (Hardcore & Tedi Hardcore) for Arcade mode.Dwarfs - F2P Endless Mode Pack (Not Recommended): Exactly like Arcade mode, except it's endless and you're allowed to pick the map size as well as the difficulty. Beware lag. Also, no high score is recorded.Dwarfs - F2P Summer Carnival Pack (Extremely NOT Recommended): Was a prize for a Steam summer sale years ago; a very simple mini-game that is completely different than the base game.Dwarfs - F2P Base Defend Pack (Not Recommended): A cute little tower defense mode that's rather different from the base game.

												This is a great game.Despite not having all of the content of the paid version, there is still much fun to be had. I have played for over an hour, and I made a video for it on my YouTube channel. It's a game that takes from many other games, and is a great RTS.WARNING! THIS REVIEW MAY CONTAIN WHAT YOU BELIEVE TO BE SPOILERS! PROCEED WITH CAUTION, FELLOW DWARF!You are the dwarf overseer, and you see what the dwarfs be doing. If they start doing something you don't like...STOP THEM!This game does require a legitimate strategy, and due to the system of caves that appear, you never know if something will make you the richest dwarf in existence, or doom you and your hall. A dangerous cave can be many blocks away from the town hall, and depending on the danger inside, you can have an entire minute to deal with the situation at your own pace before it becomes a worrying threat. Sometimes you will uncover enemies. This can be a troop of 2 spiders, to 3 orcs and to a powerful warlock. To truly tackle these requires you to use fighter dwarves, which are very powerful fighters (and good miners). They cost 100 gold each (which by the time you encounter enemies you will have enough of), and are instantly available to fight. You can place a battle tower in an area that you have mined for 500 gold, and this is VITAL to beating powerful enemies such as the warlock, as you can have up to 8 enemies. Of course, in a five minute arcade play-through, you may not need this. But in a 60 minute play through, you definitely will. My one complaint is that you can't zoom out enough to view the whole arena at once, and this can be annoying when you have a load of dwarfs doing there own thing on multiple ends of the map. This has lead to many deaths in my playthroughs. Overall, I give this game a 9/10.And to top it all off, this game has a cameo from the ultimate dwarf: Yogscast Simon! :D

												In Dwarfs!? you play the 'Dwarf Overseer' over your Dwarf's mining. The game is pretty simple. There are only two types of buildings and only two types of dwarf's. There are miner dwarf's and warrior dwarf's. Miners spawn automatically as you get more gold. Warrior's are obviously more adept to fight can be spawned at the main base (max 8) or, be spawned from the other building type, outposts. The aim of the game is to get as much gold as you can within the time limit or before your base is destroyed. The miners will dig around randomly but you can guide them to caves or minerals. However, giving them directions costs precious gold. This is where it gets incredibly fun. There are really not that many different types of hazardous areas. There's caves full of water or lava that can flood your mine and there are caves full of enemies. What's fun is that you won't see what's in the cave until a dwarf has dug into it. But the caves may have treasure within and gold is what keeps your mine in order.Once a dwarf has discovered a cave full of water or lava it you need to block it off with a wall, blow up a pit with dynamite (which require sacrificing a dwarf) and then solidify the rock around the area so your miners don't blindly spring another leak. These caves are certainly the most hazardous, especially when your mine has branched into something quite complex where water could be flowing through several shafts which all need blocked off. Caves with enemies can be dealt with warriors. You can build an outpost where you can spawn 4 warriors, train them and (best of all) shoot them out a cannon towards the enemy area. Shooting them out the cannon isn't accurate so you may get a dwarf or 2 in shafts without enemies. Again, this is where gold is much needed. Being able to build outposts allows you to be tactful with the placement. It's all really easy to control with shortcuts to items being labelled at the bottom, it's very easy to pick up and play. There are also time controls. You can pause the game for a brief moment, if things are getting a bit hectic, to look around and work with your mine. Best of all is the ability to speed up the game. It allows you to be as greedy as you can be. Both these controls don't affect your time limit per game. Which is perfect as these are tools to help your mine rather than alter the match itself.The F2P version probably has what most people want. You are only limited to Easy and Normal difficulties but Normal is good enough. There's no reason why people shouldn't give this a go. The game also features some humorous tutorials with a dwarf voiced by Yogscast's Simon which was a nice surprise. With games being timed from 15 minutes, 30 minutes or an hour, it is certainly a lot of fun to pick up and play.

												Dwarfs!? is a simple yet fun game where you don't LEAD an underground kingdom of dwarves to victory and wealth so much as you BABYSIT them. All the while YOU are responsible for hiring warrior dwarves, trapping the floods (water or lava) and directing the miners toward valuable stuff, and away from the harmful places (although it costs money to give orders or directions). The F2P game is a pretty good snag, as you get the general arcade mode on the easy and hard settings, as well as tutorial and a few challenge maps. If you want more than that, you have to buy the corresponding DLC to get the harder settings and the other modes offered in the game, which sadly the future Tripwire is leaning toward. Overall, fun, challenging little game that can offer more if you buy the entire game (with all DLC), and if you're a Killing Floor fan, this game has the achievement that will get you the Dwarven Axe on Killing Floor.

You start out with a single great hall while miner dwarves slowly come into existence and dig their way outward, discovering caves, treasure, valuable minerals, not so valuable minerals, floods, lava pools, monsters and so on. All the while YOU are responsible for hiring warrior dwarves, trapping the floods (water or lava) and directing the miners toward valuable stuff, and away from the harmful places (although it costs money to give orders or directions). The F2P game is a pretty good snag, as you get the general arcade mode on the easy and hard settings, as well as tutorial and a few challenge maps. If you want more than that, you have to buy the corresponding DLC to get the harder settings and the other modes offered in the game, which sadly the future Tripwire is leaning toward. 												This is a game for people who think fast and act faster. The player does not have complete control over the dwarfs mining; you may guide some of their actions but ultimately you will have too many of them to guide every single one and then they'll dig in whatever direction they want. Your job is to guide them to gems and precious metals and see to it that they don't dig into caves with lava or water, thus flooding the cave and killing all dwarfs. To avoid floods, you have to block or blow holes in the ground. This, however, comes at a cost and thus is one of the reasons to why you have to find gems and precious metals early in the game.The game's graphics has an old look to them, with a horrendously old-fashioned main menu design, which put me off at first. However, while playing the game the design is not bad and has a more "retro" feel to it. I rather liked the different maps and tutorials. The game seriously tested my patience, though, and I did not enjoy playing under constant pressure.

												TL,DR; PLAY NAO MLG-PRO"Dwarfs" is a very deceptive game. True, there are only a few game mechanics, and almost everything is automated, but It's not as "casual" as it'd like you to believe.There are all these caves, and when a digger dwarf accesses one, it might have monsters, gold, water, lava, or nothing at all. The further out they expand, the more caves you have access to. As a consequence of this, the creation of your very own Moria increases exponentially.The monsters can be fought by the second type of dwarf, the Soldier, which can come from your main base, or from the only building you can build, Outposts.Water has to be walled off, and then blocked off with indestructable rock (at an expense.)Lava is slower than lava, but can melt through the walls. This requires more long-term solutions, but can be dealt with in a similar way to water.So, when does a REALLY HARD mechanic come into play?It doesn't. WAIT WAIT HOLD ON.The individual mechanics are easy to deal with, but ANY OF THEM WITHOUT ADVANCE WARNING?As a game of "Dwarfs" continues, the dwarven diggers dig deeper and deeper. Naturally, they come across more caves. at increasing frequency.How deep is too deep? That's what this game is all about.You're constantly on edge, and worrying about anything and everything going wrong.Entering a new cave is a consistantly sphincter-tightening experience. (yes, i did just use those words that way.)If you think to yourself, "Hey, i can dig out little passages and mine precious metals... THIS IS DUNGEON KEEPER!! RIPOFF!!"No, it's not.
